titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to Boston with Mrs: Allen— Attended at the Supreme Court, which adjourned, without trying any of the Causes, for which I was present— Call’d at Mr: Brooks’s Office— Executed the lease with Mr: Delisle. Dined at Dr: Welsh’s. He was himself however not at home— Returned to Quincy in the Evening.

2. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham— Read the 13th: and 14th: Sermons of Butler; on the Love of God— And the 15th: on the Ignorance of Man— Wrote to Mrs: Adams in the Evening— This was the third successive day of extreme heat, and in the afternoon we had a slight thunder-shower.

3. Briesler was here this morning; going to Hanover.— I finished analyzing the Laws of the last Session of Congress, and began with the Treaties— Read a Chapter in Aristotle, and the 16th: Iliad in both Translations— Pope gives up the Death of Patroclus to the critics; and it is indeed hardly to be justified.

4. This was the day for the annual meeting of the proprietors of Neponset Bridge, but I did not attend it. I was occupied as usual the whole day— Read the 17th: Iliad in both translations— It is merely the contest for the dead body of Patroclus— Its most famous passage is the prayer of Ajax for day-light— My brother was all day at Weymouth— Recd: a letter from Mrs: Adams.

5. My Mother and Brother went this morning for Atkinson to spend a few days there— I went out an hour before dinner and shot some larks— In the evening Captain Beale, Mr: W. Baxter and C. Bracket came to invite us to dinner from the Masons, at the installation to be the 19th: of this month— I finished the analysis of the Treaties, published with the last Session’s Laws of Congress— And read Pope’s 18th: Iliad, with the description of the Armour of Achilles, made by Vulcan.

6. Mrs: Bass here at dinner.— Planted wild cherries— Read in Aristotle; and this afternoon, Cowper’s 18th: Iliad, with Pope’s dissertation on the Shield of Achilles— In the evening, a Play of Kotzebue.

7. I continue to employ an hour or two in the morning upon the Laws of the United States— This forenoon I was occupied full two hours in seeking the Treatise on the shield of Achilles; by Court de Gebelin—but that volume is missing— I had not my full hour left for a chapter of Aristotle— In the afternoon I read in Bryant’s Mythology and Pope’s 19th: Iliad— In the evening part of a play of Kotzebue.

8. My father dined with Mr: T. Greenleaf and the club— I was assiduously employed the whole day; and I hope to some purpose.— Read the 19th: Iliad in Cowper’s Translation, and in the Evening finished the 9th: volume of Kotzebue’s plays.

9. Heard Mr: Elliot of Watertown— On the declaration that Time should be no longer— Read three Sermons of Butler— On public occasions— Before the Society for propagating the Gospel— The Lord Mayor, and Governors of the charitable hospitals— And the House of Lords, on the 30th: of January— The last has some good observations on hypocrisy.— I went up to Mr: Cranch’s this Evening— Wrote to Mrs: Adams.

10. Call’d at Mr: Arnold’s this morning— At Mr: Greenleaf’s on returning.— Read Buffon on the Panther &c— And the 20th: Iliad in both Translations— In the evening the third Book of Southey’s Joan of Arc.

11. Bathed this morning at Mr: Black’s lower wharf— My mother and brother return’d from Atkinson. I finished the first Book of Aristotle’s Rhetoric; and read the 21st: Iliad in both Translations— It contains the fight in the River Scamander, and the Battle of the Gods.— One remark I make in comparing the Translations with the original is that Pope in his departures from it almost always generalizes ideas which there are special. It gives a moral and sententious turn to the work, which does not belong to it— I have noted many such passages.

12. Confined to the house by the foul weather— Began the second Book of Aristotle’s Rhetoric; in the afternoon read the two translation of 22d. Iliad— Containing the Death of Hector— Pope pronounces this the most beautiful book of the whole Poem.— In the evening I read Court de Gebelin’s dissertation on the shield of Achilles, and a book of Southey’s Joan.

13. Weather cleared off this afternoon, and in the Evening I walked round by Mr: Cranch’s— Mrs: Cranch was here this afternoon— I read the 23d: Iliad in the two Translations, containing the funeral games in honour of Patroclus— Pope shines in this Book, as in many others— But Homer has not told us, how Ulysses, Diomed, and several others had recovered from their wounds so soon to take part in the games.

14. Went into Boston this morning with my brother— Call’d twice to see Mr: Dexter without finding him, at his office— Met Judge Davis, and went to his Office, where we look’d over the volume of the Academy’s papers just ready for publication— At the Fire and Marine Insurance Office— Dined with Mr: W. Sullivan— His lady, is out of town, at Nahant— Mr: Palaeske, formerly the Prussian Consul, and whom in 1800 I saw at Berlin, Mr: T. C. Amory, and Mr: J. T. Sargent were there— We return’d in the Evening to Quincy— My Mother is quite unwell— Confined to her chamber all day.

15. Coll: Humphreys and Mr: Short were here this morning, on a visit to my father— My brother dined at the club with Mr: D. Greenleaf— In the evening I walk’d round the Square, and call’d at Mr: Barrett’s. Finished reading the translations of the Iliad by Pope and Cowper— I had not before read Cowper’s Homer, nor the notes to Pope’s— I have occasionally compared parts of both in almost every book with the original— The likeness is the greatest in Cowper; but Pope has beauties of his own, which more than compensate for every thing he omits of the author— There are however omissions by him sometimes too great— See for instance in the Speech of Patroclus’s Ghost to Achilles 23d: Iliad, six lines of the original totally omitted.

16. Heard Mr: Whitney. read three Sermons of Butler on Charity Schools, on the Anniversary of the accession of George the Second, and on the London Infirmary— Read also the Introduction and first Chapter of the same Author’s Analogy, of Natural and Revealed Religion to the Constitution and Course of Nature.— Wrote to Mrs: Adams, and in the Evening carried the letter to Mr: Cranch’s.

17. Morning excessively warm, but the weather grew cool and became rainy before Night— I bathed at Mr: Black’s wharf— Besides my steady forenoon occupation, I read this afternoon Rapin’s parallel, between Homer and Virgil, where with some truth, and good criticism, there are many errors— The method, borrowed from Aristotle, is very good— In the evening read 1st: Book of Hudibras— My brother went with Mr: T. Greenleaf to Stoughton, and return’d this Evening.

18. Cold and rainy day.— Morning employed as usual. In the afternoon I read Rapin’s comparison between Demosthenes and Cicero, which I think more judicious than that of Homer and Virgil. In the Evening a Book of Southey’s delegated Maid. Captn: Beale was here great part of the Evening.

19. Attended by invitation of the Rural Lodge of Free-Masons, instituted in this Town, at their installation; the ceremonies of which were performed at the Meeting-House— The company met at Mr: W. Baxter, and the Lodge, together with the Royal Arch Lodge from Boston, who came to install them, went in procession to Church— The invited Company followed them.— After a Short prayer by Mr: Harris, a Sermon by Mr: Whitney, and some Musical performances, the Officers of the New Lodge, were invested by those of the Royal-Arch with their Badges— After the Ceremonies were concluded, the Lodges, together with their invited guests, dined at the Hall— About 130 persons were present— The dinner was not long; and two or three songs, with a few toasts finished the business— Dr: Bartlett of Charlestown, and a Mr: Harrison called, on their return home— Dr: Tufts and his Lady, and part of Mr: Smith’s family from Boston were also here— Mr: Palaeske came up from Boston and dined here— But he was gone before I came home— In the Evening I read the 9th: Book, of Joan of Arc— Containing the vision; which is worth all the rest of the Poem, and more.

20. My brother went to Randolph on business.— This afternoon I read Rapin’s comparison between Thucydides and Livy— It is entertaining; but the method not having been carved out before hand by Aristotle, as in the case of the two former parallels is not so good— I also read over in the Port-Folio most of my letters on Silesia, which by an advertisement in the Newspapers appear to have been republished in London, in a Volume— I find part of one Letter from Leipzig, relating to Lord Holland and Mr: Elliot, which I always much regretted to see published, and which I shall regret still more if it is included in the republication— Mr: Elliot particularly, who will naturally suppose, if the book should ever fall into his hands that it was published by my consent, must think himself very ill-treated by me, in return for his civilities; by an allusion to his domestic History, which must be disagreeable to him and his family— But in writing the Silesian letters, I had no expectation that any of them would be published, and I certainly never should have written that one, had I imagined it would have appeared in print.

21. My brother and Louisa Smith went down upon a party to Squantum, which failed. In the evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s, with the volume of his Son’s Reports— Found him very unwell, with an Inflammation in his legs— I read Part of Rapin’s Comparison between Plato and Aristotle.

22. This morning I finished the Chronological index to the Laws and Treaties of the United States; and in order to be possess’d of the Judicial Constructions which have been given to them I began reading the part of Dallas’s Reports, which contains the adjudications of the Courts of the Union— Read the decisions of the federal Court of Appeals under the old Confederation, which are few and of little consequence— Dr: Tufts was here— My brother dined with the Club at Mr: Barrett’s— In the afternoon I finished the volume of Rapin’s Comparisons; with the History of the Platonic and Aristotelian Doctrines— Went down to Mr: Quincy’s, and past the Evening. Read the prefaces and first Canto, of Fessenden’s Terrible Tractoration.

23. Heard Mr: Whitney.— Read further in Butler’s Analogy— Also the Article Bible, in the Encyclopaedia. In the Evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s, where I found Mr: Whitney, Mr: Barrett and Captain Brackett, who has just returned from a voyage to the Senegal river— Mr: Cranch himself in confined to his chamber, and we did not see him—

24. Employed the forenoon, in reading Dallas’s Reports— Vol: 2. Adjudications in the U.S. Circuit Court Pennsyla. and in the afternoon, Smith’s Thucydides, Book 1.— Short walk for exercise, before dinner, and in the Evening. Weather Cold.

25. My brother went to Dedham to attend the Court of Common-Pleas— My Mother and Louisa went into Boston, but returned this Evening— Mr: Quincy pass’d an hour with me this forenoon.— In the Evening I called at Mr: Cranch’s— Found him much better— Mrs: Norton was there— Her son Thomas, has been very ill; but is recovering.— I was employed the day through with Dallas’s Reports— (Finished the second Volume) Thucydides—of whom I read the second Book— And in the Evening Hudibras.

26. I find myself overtasked, by the portion of reading I have assumed to perform— I read however this morning, part of Dallas’s third Volume— And this afternoon the third Book of Thucydides— I could no more— Captain Beale, was here this afternoon— As was his son Richard— Mr: Quincy also, brought me the first Volume of Aikin’s annual Review, which I had not time to look into— Wrote this Evening, for Mr: R. Beale. Walk round the Square.

27. Mr: Cranch was here this morning— Mrs: Miller, with Mr: and Mrs: D. Greenleaf in the Evening— And also Mr: T. Greenleaf who has been to Dedham.— Read Dallas—the fourth Book of Thucydides; and in the Evening the 1st: Canto, 2d: Part of Hudibras— Heard of the death of President Willard at New-Bedford, the 25th.

28. Mr: Quincy was here about an hour, this morning— My Aunt Smith spent the day here— I went home with her— Call’d at Mr: Cranch’s: where I found Mr: & Mrs: Norton— Mr: Montague pass’d the Evening with us. Received a letter from my wife— She and my youngest child have both been very ill; but thank Heaven, were recovering.— Received also a letter from Mr: Dennie.— Read Dallas in the forenoon; and the 5th: Book of Thucydides after dinner— Also a Canto of Hudibras, in the Evening.

29. The Gentlemen of the Club, dined at my father’s; but he was under a necessity of attending the funeral of President Willard, at Cambridge, where I accompanied him; and my brother had not return’d from the Court at Dedham.— We took a light dinner between 11. and 12 o’clock, and immediately afterwards proceeded to Cambridge, where we arrived just at 2. Called at Mr: Greenleaf’s; and paid also a visit to Mr: Gerry.— At 3 we went to the President’s House, where the company was collecting, but it was nearly 5 before they proceeded to the meeting house— A prayer was made by Dr: Lathrop, and an Eulogy on the deceased by Professor Webber— A concluding prayer by Mr: Holmes the Minister of Cambridge— The funeral procession then went, preceded by the Students, round part of the town; up through the College-Yard to the Church-Yard— Part of them then returned to his house— It was now past 7. in the Evening, & dark— We return’d however to Quincy, and got home about 1/2 past 9 in the Evening— Found my brother, return’d from Dedham.

30. Heard Mr: Whitney— Read several chapters in Butler’s Analogy— Wrote letters to my wife and to J. Dennie. In the Evening, I carried them up to Mr: Cranch’s, and sat about an hour with him.— Mr: Savage the Painter, was here this afternoon.

Day. Rise between Six and Seven— Breakfast soon after— Read till Noon— Walk about half an hour. dine— Read untill dark— Walk again, a half an hour— Pass the Evening untill 9 in conversation, with my father, and read a little poetry, or something as light before going to bed.
